response: Track your expenses daily to identify unnecessary spending.
Create a budget that allocates 50% of your income to needs, 30% to wants, and 20% to savings.
Consider using budgeting apps like Mint or You Need a Budget (YNAB) for better financial tracking.
Build an emergency fund with at least 3 to 6 months' worth of living expenses.
Opt for a student credit card to build your credit score but use it responsibly.
Take advantage of student discounts to save on everyday expenses.
Look for part-time jobs or internships to supplement your income during college.
Invest early, even with small amounts, to benefit from compound growth.
Avoid impulse purchases by making a shopping list and sticking to it.
Prioritize paying off high-interest debts, like credit card balances, as soon as possible.
Use free resources like the public library or university services to save on books and software.
Plan meals in advance to avoid eating out frequently and save money.
Set financial goals and regularly review your progress to stay motivated.
Use second-hand stores or online marketplaces for affordable furniture and supplies.
Check for tax benefits like tuition tax credits available for Canadian students.
Contribute to a TFSA (Tax-Free Savings Account) as early as possible to maximize savings.
Shop for groceries at budget-friendly stores and buy in bulk to save money.
Learn basic cooking skills to save on eating out and improve your health.
Review your phone and internet plans to ensure you're not overspending.
Participate in university clubs and events for free or discounted experiences.
